A 54-year-old thin female ( $51 \mathrm{~kg}, 5^{\prime} 5^{\prime \prime}$ ) with a history of shor
A. Continue same 10 mL daily dose until the supply is exhausted
B. Only provide 10 mL on Mondays each week
C. Only provide 10 mL on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays each week
D. Switch to standard dose of oral multivitamin 3 days per week
A 69-year-old diabetic male with bowel obstruction from colon cancer is to be sent home on PN. Durin
A. Stress of being hospitalized has resolved and his insulin needs are lower.
B. His HPN formulation was incorrectly compounded with less dextrose than in the hospital.
C. He is not receiving his HPN daily as instructed.
D. He has received more insulin than prescribed.

blocks.section: STRATEGIES FOR MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES
STRATEGIES FOR MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES
blocks.preview: - PN product shortages have occurred since 1988

blocks.section: STRATEGIES FOR MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES
blocks.preview: - Mostly isolated to IV multivitamins

blocks.section: STRATEGIES FOR MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES
blocks.preview: - Deaths from thiamine deficiency resulting in refractory lactic acidosis

blocks.section: STRATEGIES FOR MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES
blocks.preview: - 2010-2011 shortages resulted in almost every PN component used

blocks.section: STRATEGIES FOR MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES
blocks.preview: - FDA regulations, inspections, recalls, issues with raw materials, demand, loss of manufacturing si

blocks.section: STRATEGIES FOR MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES
blocks.preview: - Substitute PN products must be evaluated for compatibility/stability with other ingredients in PN

blocks.section: STRATEGIES FOR MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES
blocks.preview: - Communicate information to clinical staff

blocks.section: STRATEGIES FOR MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES
blocks.preview: - Prioritize patients and manage inventory

blocks.preview: Holcombe B et al. Nutr Clin Pract. 2018; 33(1):53-61.

blocks.section: MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES - AMINO ACIDS
MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES - AMINO ACIDS
blocks.preview: - Amino acids shortage strategies:

blocks.section: MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES - AMINO ACIDS
blocks.preview: - Reserve high (e.g., > 10\%) concentration amino acids for fluid-restricted PN patients

blocks.section: MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES - AMINO ACIDS
blocks.preview: - Review entire portfolio of amino acids products available nationally

blocks.section: MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES - AMINO ACIDS
blocks.preview: - Other concentrations may be available (e.g., 8.5\%)

blocks.section: MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES - AMINO ACIDS
blocks.preview: - Different brands of amino acids products are not always substitutable

blocks.section: MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES - AMINO ACIDS
blocks.preview: - Different pH , calcium-phosphate solubility, amounts of phosphate and other electrolytes (e.g., so

blocks.section: MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES - AMINO ACIDS
blocks.preview: - Compound in a single, central location to decrease inventory waste

blocks.section: MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES - AMINO ACIDS
blocks.preview: - Evaluate need for each amino acid product on ACD

blocks.section: MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES - AMINO ACIDS

blocks.preview: - ILE shortage strategies:
- Prioritize supply of soybean oil ILE
- Hospitalized patients on PN for $>2$ weeks
- Home or long-term patients on PN
- 100 g weekly for EFAD prevention
- Critically ill patients on PN receiving propofol do NOT require additional ILE for EFAD prevention
- Propofol is formulated in 10\% soybean oil ILE
- Consider using an alternative ILE containing soybean oil
- Monitor PN patients for risk of developing EFAD
Plogsted S et al. Nutr Clin Pract. 2017;32(3):427-29.
- Electrolytes and minerals shortage strategies:
- Consider switching to oral or enterally administered electrolyte or mineral supplement products wh
- Malabsorption syndromes or nonfunctional Gl tract may preclude use
- Reserve IV electrolyte and mineral products for patients requiring PN
- Therapeutic medical need for IV electrolyte and mineral products
- Reconsider use of serum electrolyte algorithms or protocols in asymptomatic patients to conserve i
- Assess PN patient population to determine if a standardized, commerciallyavailable PN product with
- IV Multivitamin shortage strategies:
- Reserve for patients receiving solely PN or therapeutic medical need
- Ration to dosing 3 times a week to conserve inventory
- Monitor for vitamin deficiencies during rationing
- Complete shortage - use individual thiamine, ascorbic acid, pyridoxine, folic acid, cyanocobalamin
- Consider switching to oral or enterally administered multivitamins when feasible
- Review vitamin profile of each product to be used for completeness
- Higher doses may be required in malabsorption syndromes
Plogsted S et al. Nutr Clin Pract. 2016; 31(4):556-9.

MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES - TRACE ELEMENTS
blocks.preview: - IV trace elements shortage strategies:

blocks.section: MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES - TRACE ELEMENTS
blocks.preview: - Reserve for patients receiving solely PN or therapeutic medical need

blocks.section: MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES - TRACE ELEMENTS
blocks.preview: - Ration to dosing 3 times a week to conserve inventory

blocks.section: MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES - TRACE ELEMENTS
blocks.preview: - Complete shortage - use individual zinc, selenium, copper

blocks.section: MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES - TRACE ELEMENTS
blocks.preview: - Monitor for trace element deficiencies

blocks.section: MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES - TRACE ELEMENTS
blocks.preview: - Consider switching to oral or enterally administered multitrace supplements when feasible

blocks.section: MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES - TRACE ELEMENTS
blocks.preview: - Review trace element profile of each product to be used for completeness

blocks.section: MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES - TRACE ELEMENTS
blocks.preview: - Higher doses may be required in malabsorption syndromes

blocks.section: MANAGING PN PRODUCT SHORTAGES - TRACE ELEMENTS

blocks.preview: - Determine final concentrations:
- Dextrose 16\%, Amino Acids 5.5\%, ILE $2.3 \%$
- 206 mEq Sodium/L
- 99 mEq Potassium/L
- 305 mEq/L of monovalent cations
- 45 mmol Phosphate/L
- 7 mEq Magnesium/L
- 6 mEq Calcium/L
- 13 mEq/L of divalent cations
- It is recommended that TNAs maintain final concentrations of monohydrated dextrose $\geq 10 \%$, a
- Current TNA formulation meets these recommendations
- Sodium content is recommended to have a maximum of $150 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}$
- Current TNA has 206 mEq sodium/L
- Also exceeds recommended 1-2 mEq/kg/day at 5.6 mEq sodium/kg/day
- Potassium content recommended is 1-2 mEq/kg/day
- Current TNA provides 2.7 mEq potassium $/ \mathrm{kg} /$ day
- Commercially available ILEs are stabilized with egg yolk phosphatides providing a mechanical and e
- Phospholipid mixture imparts negative surface (anionic surfactant) charge on emulsified lipid part
- Addition of cations to a TNA neutralize the negative charge on the surface of the lipid particles
- Monovalent $=$ Sodium + Potassium
- Divalent $=$ Magnesium + Calcium
- Trivalent $=$ Iron dextran (greatest impact on destabilization)
Boullata Jlet al. JPEN J Parenter Enteral Nutr. 2014; 38(3):334-77.
Driscoll DF et al. AmJ Health-Syst Pharm. 1995;52:623-34.
- Commercially available ILEs may exhibit the following characteristics:
- Creaming occurs when the electrostatic barrier is neutralized
- Single lipid droplets form aggregates and migrate to surface of the TNA
- Described as dense white color at the top of a TNA
- Heavy creaming occurs prior to "cracking" where the oil globules coalesce on the surface and separ
- Unsafe for infusion if heavy creaming or "cracked" marbled appearance in TNA visible
- Oil globules $>5$ microns in size pose the risk of pulmonary embolism
- Commercially available ILEs are heavily influenced by the cations and may lead to lipid destabiliz
- $305 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}$ of monovalent cations with Sodium and Potassium
- Ranges in the literature have been up to $150 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}$
- This TNA requires reformulation with a lower sodium and potassium concentration
- $13 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}$ of divalent cations with Magnesium and Calcium
- Ranges in the literature have been up to $20 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}$
- This TNA contains reasonable amounts of divalent cations
Boullata Jlet al. JPEN J Parenter Enteral Nutr. 2014; 38(3):334-77.
Driscoll DF et al. AmJ Health-Syst Pharm. 1995;52:623-34.

blocks.preview: Driscoll DF, et al. AmJ Health-SystPharm1995;52:623-34.
- Dextrose 16\%, Amino Acids 5.5\%, ILE 2.3\%
- 45 mmol Phosphate/L
- 6 mEq Calcium/L
- Appears to be compatible; however this Calcium-Phosphate compatible curve was based upon stability
- Affected by pH , temperature, order of mixing, agitation, calcium salt used, storage time, visual
Anon. Calcium/phosphate solubility curves: Clínisol (Amino Acids) Injection. Baxter Healthcare Inc.
- January 1994
- 2 patients died suddenly after receiving peripheral TNA
- Clinical diagnosis was pulmonary embolus
- Both autopsies revealed amorphous deposits of calcium-phosphate in the pulmonary vasculature
- Hospital switched from Travasol to FreAmine III
- FreAmine III contains 10 $\mathrm{mmol} / \mathrm{L}$ of phosphate
- Retrospective review identified 5 patients (out of 50 who received the TNA)
- Bilateral interstitial infiltrates
- 4 of 5 died within a median of 48 hrs on the TNA
Shay DK et al. Infect Control Hosp Epidemiol. 1997; 18:814-7.

IMPORTANCE OF IN-LINE FILTRATION OF PN
IMPORTANCE OF IN-LINE FILTRATION OF PN
blocks.preview: - Mean droplet size of commercially-available ILE is between 0.2-0.5 microns

blocks.section: IMPORTANCE OF IN-LINE FILTRATION OF PN
blocks.preview: - Particulates are common in most large volume injectables

blocks.section: IMPORTANCE OF IN-LINE FILTRATION OF PN
blocks.preview: - Foreign particles can produce phlebitis

blocks.section: IMPORTANCE OF IN-LINE FILTRATION OF PN
blocks.preview: - Peripheral $>$ central venous access

blocks.section: IMPORTANCE OF IN-LINE FILTRATION OF PN
blocks.preview: - Microprecipitates may lead to catheter occlusion

blocks.section: IMPORTANCE OF IN-LINE FILTRATION OF PN
blocks.preview: - Solubility of calcium \& phosphate is not entirely predictable

blocks.section: IMPORTANCE OF IN-LINE FILTRATION OF PN
blocks.preview: - 1.2 micron in-line filter will reduce these problems and can filter microorganisms (e.g., Candida

blocks.section: IMPORTANCE OF IN-LINE FILTRATION OF PN
blocks.preview: - Should be used for no longer than 24 hours

blocks.preview: - Verbal instructions given to patient and caregiver regarding complications associated with HPN and
- Oley PN Complication Chart (www.oley.org)
- Patient and caregiver receive diabetic teaching with glucometer prior to discharge (if appropriate
- Verbal instructions given to patient and caregiver regarding signs and symptoms of hypoglycemia as
- When to administer carbohydrate (e.g., Dextrose 50\%) and notify physician
- Hands-on instruction of addition of other medications to HPN
- IV Multivitamins, regular insulin, H2 antagonists
- Verification of HPN label with patient or caregiver
- Correct patient
- Ingredients (dextrose, amino acids, ILE, electrolytes, micronutrients \& medications) listed as am
- Beyond use date checked
- Visual instructions on the identification of a cracked HPN formulation discussed with patient and
- With instructions on when not to use the HPN formulation
- Importance of 1.2 micron in-line filter at all times during HPN infusion
- Monitoring: Periodic blood draws
- Consider patient accessibility, cost and frequency of labs

blocks.section: LIMITATIONS OR ASSUMPTIONS IN HPN EDUCATION
LIMITATIONS OR ASSUMPTIONS IN HPN EDUCATION
blocks.preview: - Nurse is generally NOT present

blocks.section: LIMITATIONS OR ASSUMPTIONS IN HPN EDUCATION
blocks.preview: - Seven bags of HPN are sent on a weekly basis (depending on prescriber)

blocks.section: LIMITATIONS OR ASSUMPTIONS IN HPN EDUCATION
blocks.preview: - Patient and/or caregiver will be able to learn what needs to be done, including:

blocks.section: LIMITATIONS OR ASSUMPTIONS IN HPN EDUCATION
blocks.preview: - Catheter care, HPN preparation, HPN administration, IV pump management

blocks.section: LIMITATIONS OR ASSUMPTIONS IN HPN EDUCATION
blocks.preview: - Most patients 'cycle at night'

blocks.section: LIMITATIONS OR ASSUMPTIONS IN HPN EDUCATION
blocks.preview: - Frequent urination may impede sleep cycle

blocks.section: LIMITATIONS OR ASSUMPTIONS IN HPN EDUCATION
blocks.preview: - Can the patient physically carry the HPN bag around their residence?

blocks.section: LIMITATIONS OR ASSUMPTIONS IN HPN EDUCATION
blocks.preview: - Compliance issues (e.g., Are they really following the daily infusions?)

blocks.section: LIMITATIONS OR ASSUMPTIONS IN HPN EDUCATION
blocks.preview: - Restarts upon hospital discharges

blocks.section: LIMITATIONS OR ASSUMPTIONS IN HPN EDUCATION
blocks.preview: - Discarding expired HPNs

blocks.section: LIMITATIONS OR ASSUMPTIONS IN HPN EDUCATION
blocks.preview: - End of life issues (or when do we stop HPN)
- Patients may not be at their permanent residence for a number of reasons
- Unable to care for themselves independently
- Amount of storage space needed for ancillary drugs (e.g., $0.9 \% \mathrm{NaCl}$ flushes) and supp
- Temporary living areas (e.g., hotel or recreational vehicle) limited
- Amount of refrigerated space needed for HPN formulations and additives (e.g., IV multivitamins)
- Access to full size refrigerator
